'''Torsion disorder''' (abnormality of rotation in the transverse axis): excessive internal rotation in young children ("foot in" physiological up to 7 years), excessive external rotation in older children. Most often progresses favourably with growth. No orthopaedic treatment. Surgery is exceptional

'''Genu varum''' (anomaly of rotation in the frontal axis): intercondylar spacing, physiological up to 3 years of age

''Genu valgum'' (anomaly of rotation in the frontal axis): intermaleolar spacing, physiological from 3 to 10 years of age, disappears at puberty.

properties.question: Which of the following is the correct description of genu varum in children?
properties.option_a: Excessive internal rotation in young children, which usually resolves with growth.
properties.option_b: Excessive external rotation in older children, often requiring surgical intervention.
properties.option_c: Intercondylar spacing, physiological up to 3 years of age.
properties.option_d: Intermaleolar spacing, physiological from 3 to 10 years of age, disappearing at puberty.
